questions.question: An ________ projection is one that preserves direction for all straight lines passing through a single, specified point.

explanations.a: A conformal projection is a map projection that favors preserving the shape of features on the map but may greatly distort the size of features.
explanations.b: A Equidistant projection maintains scale along one or more lines, or from one or two points to all other points on the map
explanations.c: Correct Answer.  A map projection in which a globe, as of the Earth, is assumed to rest on a flat surface onto which its features are projected.
explanations.d: Azimuthal projection is one that preserves direction for all straight lines passing through a single, specified point.

questions.question: The Universal Polar Stereographic (UPS) is defined above ________ degrees north latitude and south of ________ degrees south latitude.

explanations.a: The Universal Polar Stereographic (UPS) is defined above 84N degrees north latitude and south of 80S degrees south latitude.
explanations.b: The Universal Polar Stereographic (UPS) is defined above 84N degrees north latitude and south of 80S degrees south latitude.
explanations.c: The Universal Polar Stereographic (UPS) is defined above 84N degrees north latitude and south of 80S degrees south latitude.
explanations.d: Correct Answer. The Universal Polar Stereographic (UPS) is defined above 84N degrees north latitude and south of 80S degrees south latitude.

questions.question: In the process of georeferencing, what is the term used for the known coordinates or reference points?

explanations.a: Projections refer to the mathematical methods used to represent the curved surface of the Earth on a flat map, not specific reference points.
explanations.b: Correct Answer. Control points are known geographic coordinates or reference points used in georeferencing to align spatial data with real-world locations.
explanations.c: Gridlines are the lines on a map representing the coordinate system (e.g., latitude and longitude), but they are not specific reference points.
explanations.d: A datum defines the size and shape of the Earth and serves as a reference framework for coordinates, but it is not used for pinpointing specific reference locations like control points.
